====Federal constitutional monarchies==== Federal constitutional monarchies are [[federal state]]s in which a number of [[federated state|federated entities]] are unified under a [[federal government]] and a single monarch, who acts as ceremonial [[head of state]]. * [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands]] (1815–1830) * '''[[Canada]]''' (1867–present) *[[German Empire]] (1871–1918; dissolved after World War I and became the [[Weimar Republic]]) * '''[[Commonwealth of Australia]]''' (1901–present) * [[Federation of Malaya]] (1957–1963; became [[Malaysia]]) * '''[[Malaysia]]''' (1963–present) * '''[[United Arab Emirates]]''' (1971–present) * '''[[Belgium|Kingdom of Belgium]]''' (1980–present)

===Absolute monarchies=== An [[absolute monarchy]] is a [[monarchy|monarchical]] [[form of government]] where the ruler has the power to rule his or her land or [[country]] and its citizens freely, with no [[law]]s or legally-organized direct opposition in force.
====Unitary absolute monarchies==== Unitary absolute monarchies are [[unitary state]]s which are governed as one single unit by a single hereditary or elected leader. Some had or have a single legislature, which may or may not be constitutionally created.

within the [[United Arab Emirates]])
==Shared monarchies== A monarch may reign over multiple kingdoms, [[dominion]]s or [[realms]] in various forms of [[political union|political]], [[dynastic union|dynastic]], [[personal union]] or association. * Between 925 and 1035 the [[Kingdom of Aragon]] shared a monarchy with the [[Kingdom of Navarre]]. * From 1150 to 1319, the [[Kingdom of Aragon]] and the [[County of Barcelona]] (actually the [[Principality of Catalonia]]) formed a dinastical union named [[Crown of Aragon]]; from 1319 to 1479, the Crown was a federation of these two countries and the [[Kingdom of Valencia]]. * The Kingdoms of [[Kingdom of León|León]] and [[Crown of Castile|Castile]] were united three times under the same monarch, first between 1037 and 1078, again from 1072 to 1157, and finally between 1230 and sometime in the 16th century. * Between 1072 and 1095 León, Castile, and Galicia were united under a common monarch, whereafter Portugal separated under a different dynasty, and the others were absorbed by [[Spain]]. * The [[Kalmar Union]] was a period between 1397 and 1536 in which [[Denmark]], [[Norway]] and [[Sweden]] shared the same monarch as three independent countries. [[Norway]] and [[Denmark]] continued to share a monarchy from 1536 to 1814. [[Union between Sweden and Norway|Norway was then united under a common monarchy with Sweden]] from 1814 to 1905. * From 1490 to c. 1740 [[Hungary]] and [[Bohemia]] (part of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]) shared a monarchy. These kingdoms shared a monarch from the [[Habsburgs]] who were Archdukes of Austria and Holy Roman Emperors. Briefly [[Naples]] and [[Sardinia]] in 1707, and [[Sicily]] in 1714 to their departure in 1735, 1720 and 1734, respectively. The [[Habsburgs]] declared themselves Emperors of Austria in 1804. The three countries remained in this situation until the union was ended in the aftermath of [[World War I]], in 1918. The [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was the union of the [[Austrian Empire]] and the [[Kingdom of Hungary]] between 1867 and 1918 under a new constitution, the [[Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867]], or Ausgleich. * From 1541, [[Monarch|King]] [[Henry VIII of England]] was declared King of [[Ireland]], after being excommunicated by the pope and losing the title of [[Lord of Ireland]]. [[England]] and Ireland were joined in a personal union until 1603, when the [[James VI of Scotland]] became king of England and Ireland. All three crowns remained in personal union until 1707 when England and Scotland were united by the [[Acts of Union 1707]] to become the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]]. The two crowns remained under personal union until the [[Acts of Union 1800]] when the kingdoms became the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]]. This union lasted until [[Irish War of Independence|Irish Independence]] in 1921 when with the departure of the 26 southern counties of Ireland, the UK officially became the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]]. * From 1580 to 1640, [[Portugal]] was under a united monarchy with [[Spain]], in the period known as the [[Iberian Union]]. * Between 1867 and 1890 [[Luxembourg]] and the [[Netherlands]] shared the same monarch. * [[Elizabeth II]] currently reigns over 16 [[Commonwealth realm]]s. * The King of France was also the co-prince of Andorra. After the abolition of the French monarchy the co-prince is now the president of the French Republic.

page.title: List of papal tiaras in existence

revision.comment: /* List of papal tiaras still in existence */
revision.text:
The '''[[papal tiara]]''' is the [[Crown (headgear)|crown]] worn by popes of the Catholic Church for centuries, until 1978 when Pope John Paul I declined a [[papal coronation|coronation]], opting instead for an inauguration. The tiara is still used as a symbol of the papacy. It features on the [[coat of arms]] of the [[Holy See]] and of the [[Vatican City State]], though not on the pope's personal coat of arms since [[Pope Benedict XVI]] replaced the tiara on his official coat of arms with a traditional bishop's mitre. A tiara is used to crown a statue of Saint Peter in [[St. Peter's Basilica]] every year on his feast day.{{cite web| publisher = Holy See Press Office | accessdate = 30 August 2017 | language = es | title =Tiara papal | url = http://www.vatican.va/news_services/press/documentazione/documents/sp_ss_scv/insigne/triregno_sp.html | date=3 April 2001}} Popes commissioned tiaras from jewelers or received them as gifts, with a number remaining in the possession of the Holy See. In 1798, [[Roman Republic (18th century)|French troops occupied Rome]] and stole or destroyed all but one of the papal tiaras held by the Holy See. Since then popes have used or received as gifts more than twenty tiaras. Several were never worn by a pope, notably those presented as gifts since the last papal coronation in 1963. ==List of papal tiaras still in existence== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ List of papal tiaras |- !width="2%" | !width="10%" | !width="15%" bgcolor="#FFFFFF"| Name !width="8%" bgcolor="#FFFFFF"| Year !width="65%" class="unsortable" | Notes |- |1 | | Tiara of Pope Gregory XIII | 1572-1585 | The oldest surviving, made by Cristoforo Foppa.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Decoration originally included an emerald (404.5 carats) later incorporated in the [[Napoleon Tiara]].{{cite journal |title= Replies: Vatican Eemerald |journal= A Medium of Intercommunication for Literary Men, General Readers, Etc. |series= Eighth Series |volume= 9 |date= January–June 1896 |location= London |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nAo4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA9 |pages= 9–10 |first= Hartwell |last= de la Garde Grissell |accessdate=31 August 2017}} |- |2 | | Papier-mâché Tiara | 1800 | Made for the coronation of [[Pope Pius VII]] in exile in [[Venice]] following the seizure or destruction of papal tiaras by the French troops that invaded Rome in 1798. Decorated with jewels donated by local families. Worn as a lightweight alternative for decades.{{cite news | work = The Independent | accessdate = 4 September 2017 | url =https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/rhodri-marsdens-interesting-objects-pope-pius-viis-paper-crown-10116494.html | first = Rhodri | last = Marsden | title = Rhodri Marsden's Interesting Objects: Pope Pius VII's paper crown | date= 21 March 2015}} |- |3 | [[File:Napoleon tiara - original.jpg|75px]] | [[Napoleon Tiara]] | 1804 | [[Napoleon I]] gifted a tiara to [[Pope Pius VII]], who presided at his [[Coronation of Napoleon I|coronation as emperor]] in December 1804. Manufactured by [[Henri Auguste]] and [[Marie-Etienne Nitot]] of the [[Chaumet|House of Chaumet]], its decoration celebrated that coronation and the [[Concordat of 1801]]. Some of its jewels and decoration came from tiaras taken by the troops of the [[French Directory]] in 1798. It was purposely made too small and too heavy to be worn. It was later modified and worn by [[Pope Pius IX|Pius IX]] at his coronation in 1846{{cite journal |journal= The United States Catholic Magazine and Monthly Review |title=Intelligence |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FhVLAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA454 |volume= 5 |issue=8 |date= August 1846 |page=454| accessdate=31 August 2017}} and to open the [[First Vatican Council]] in 1868. It appears in [[Jacques-Louis David]]'s 1807 painting ''[[The Coronation of Napoleon]]''.{{efn|The tiara is held by someone standing just behind the pope. A sketch for the painting shows Count Rogari holding tiara.{{cite web| accessdate=31 August 2017| url=http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/art/194431 | publisher = Harvard Art Museums| title= Count Rogari Holding the Papal Tiara}}}} |- |4 | | Tiara of Pope Gregory XVI | 1834 | One of the most worn in the papal collection. Worn at times by Pius IX, Pius X and Pius XII.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} Decorated with three golden circles inlaid with diamonds over the central silver core of the crown, and above each circle a series of golden cloverleaves, inlaid with jewels. |- |5 | | Tiara of Pope Gregory XVI | 1845 | |- |6 | | Tiara of Pope Gregory XVI | date unknown | Lightweight version. |- |7 | | Tiara of Pope Pius IX | 1846 | Created in 1854. With 18,000 diamonds and 1,000 emeralds, sapphires and rubies. Relatively lightweight at two pounds, it was used at all later papal coronations.{{cite book|last1=Chico|first1=Beverly|title=Hats and Headwear around the World: A Cultural Encyclopedia: A Cultural Encyclopedia|date=2013|publisher=ABC-CLIO| page=446| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GdbYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA446&|accessdate=5 September 2017}}{{cite book| accessdate = 4 September 2017 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=VcUQAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA274& | title= The Life and Acts of Pope Leo XIII |first = Joseph Edward | last = Keller | page =274 | date= 1882 | publisher = Benziger Brothers}} Decorated with six rows of 90 pearls ad well as 16 rubies, three emeralds, a hyacinth, an aquamarine, three rubies, a sapphire, and eight gold points with five garnets and two Balas rubies first tier); 10 emeralds, 8 Balas rubies, one chrysolite, two aquamarines, six small rubies and three sapphires (second tier); 16 small Balas rubies, three larger Balas rubies, four sapphires, three hyacinths, three aquamarines, one garnet, eight gold floral ornaments each with two emeralds, one Balas ruby, a chrysolite and eight gold points, each adorned with a garnet (third tier). The crown is covered with a thin layer of gold, with eight rubies and eight emeralds, surmounted by a gold globe enamelled in blue and topped by a cross composed of 11 brilliants. |- |13 | | German Tiara | 1887 | A gift from [[Wilhelm I, German Emperor|Kaiser Wilhelm I of Germany]] in commemoration of Pope Leo XIII's [[Golden Jubilee]] as a priest.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} Decorated with 1,000 pearls. |- |14 | [[File:LeoXIIIcrown.jpg|75px]] | Paris Tiara | 1888 | A gift from the Catholics of Paris to celebrate the [[golden jubilee]] of Pope Leo XIII's ordination as a priest. By [[François-Désiré Froment-Meurice|Émile Froment-Meurice]].{{cite journal | journal = [[The Tablet]] | accessdate = 4 September 2017 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=aufcLv2wgtYC&pg=PA859& | date= 28 May 1887 | title= The Jubilee of Pope Leo XIII | page = 859| volume = 69 |issue= 2455 }} He had squelched a proposal by Lyon Catholics to raise funds for a tiara in 1878.{{cite news | work= New York Times | accessdate = 4 September 2017 | date = 1 December 1878 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1878/12/01/80738045.pdf | title = Leo XIII and Peter's Pence}} |- |15 | | Austrian Tiara | 1894 | A gift from Kaiser [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]].{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} |- |16 | | Golden Tiara | 1903 | Presented by Cardinal [[Pietro Respighi]] on behalf of the world's Catholics to commemorate the Pope Leo XIII's [[silver jubilee]] as pope.{{cite news | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1903/02/21/101307009.pdf | accessdate = 4 September 2017 | work = New York Times | date= 21 February 1903 | title=Pope Lei XIII's Jubilee}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20110929105730/http://campus.udayton.edu/mary//gallery/CincyExhibit_files/v3_slide0042_image036.jpg image] |- |17 | | Tiara of Pope Pius X | 1908 | By papal jewelers Tatani to commemorate the [[golden jubilee]] of the ordination of [[Pope Pius X]] as a priest. Made by laboratories of Scuola Beato Angelico of Milan in a modern style with minimal ornament. Half the weight of the [[Palatine tiara]] of Pius IX used at coronations from 1877 to 1958. On permanent display in the [[Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception]].{{cite news|last1=Dugan|first1=George|title=Spellman's Surprise: Pope's Tiara Is Here|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1964/12/01/spellmans-surprise-popes-tiara-is-here.html|accessdate=24 February 2017|work=New York Times|date=1 December 1964}} |- |21 | [[File:Gedenkprägung-tiara-johannes-paul-II-.jpg|75px]]

The '''Lokiriama Peace Accord''' is a peace treaty between the [[Turkana people]] of [[Kenya]] and the Matheniko of [[Uganda]] signed in December 1973 as a commitment by both parties to peacefully co-exist. The accord derives its name from [[Lokiriama]], a remote town in [[Turkana District]], North Western Kenya that is inhabited by the Turkana. A symbolic monument for this accord is situated at Lokiriama on the Kenya – Uganda border. It is believed that elders from both Turkana and Matheniko buried instruments of conflict, honey, milk and traditional brew in a pit over which the monument was constructed.<ref> Intermediate Technology Development Group East Africa (2003), Peace Bulletin Newsletter </ref>
== Commemoration of the accord ==
Celebrations to commemorate the accord and re-affirm the commitment of all parties to upholding its content are held every year. The date for commemorating the accord is not fixed and may sometimes fall in December, earlier or later. In 2011 for example, commemoration was held on [[International Day of Peace]] which falls on September 21 every year. In addition to the Turkana and Matheniko, the commemorations bring together the [[Toposa people]] and [[Didinga people]] of [[Southern Sudan]], other [[Karamojong people]] from Uganda and [[Nyangatom people|Nyangatom]] of [[Ethiopia]]. Commemorations are also graced with the presence of high-profile political and appointed leaders from all levels, including the [[central government]] for both Kenya and Uganda. Local and international [[civil society|civil society organizations]] also participate in the event often making contributions to meet various associated expenses such as media coverage, transportation of clan members and food for all attendees. The 2011 commemoration was attended by former Kenyan President [[Daniel Arap Moi]], [[Member of Parliament|Parliamentary members]], Ministers and high-profile civil servants from both Kenya and Uganda.<ref>http://www.gurtong.net/ECM/Editorial/tabid/124/ctl/ArticleView/mid/519/articleId/5752/EES-Governor-Commemorates-Lokiriama-Peace-Accord-In-Kenya.aspx </ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Lê Văn Khôi revolt |partof=[[Siamese–Vietnamese Wars]] |image=Citadel of Saigon before 1835.png |image_size=200px |caption=The French-built [[Citadel of Saigon]] was taken over by the rebels on 18 May 1833 and held more than two years until September 1835. |date= 1833–1835 |place= [[Southern Vietnam]] |result= Decisive Nguyễn Dynasty victory |combatant1= [[Lê Văn Khôi]] rebels
'''Supported by:'''
{{flagicon image|Flag of Thailand (1817).svg}} [[Rattanakosin Kingdom]] ([[Siam]]) |combatant2= {{flagicon image|}} [[Nguyễn Dynasty]] |commander1=[[Lê Văn Khôi]] {{KIA}}
[[Nguyen Van Tam (catholic priest)|Nguyen Van Tam]]{{KIA}}
[[Le Van Cu]]{{Executed}}
[[Joseph Marchand]]{{Executed}} |commander2=[[Truong Minh Giang]] |strength1=Siamese troops and 2,000 Vietnamese Catholic troops McLeod, p. 31 |strength2=Unknown |casualties1=1,831 people were executed
Only 6 survivors were temporarily sparedNghia M. Vo – Saigon: A History – Page 53 2011 "The six principal leaders were sent to Huế to be executed. Among them were the French missionary Marchand, accused of being the leader of the Catholic rebel group; Nguyễn Văn Trấm, the leader of the hồi lương who took the command of the revolt after Lê Văn Khôi's death in 1834; and Lưu Tín, the Chinese leader." |casualties2=Unknown }} The '''Lê Văn Khôi revolt''' (1833–1835) was an important revolt in 19th century [[Vietnam]], in which southern Vietnamese, Vietnamese Catholics, [[Paris Foreign Missions Society|French Catholic missionaries]] and [[Hoa people|Chinese settlers]] under the leadership of [[Lê Văn Khôi]] opposed the Imperial rule of [[Minh Mạng]]. ==Origin== The revolt was spurred by the prosecutions launched by Minh Mạng against southern factions which had opposed his rule and tended to be favourable to Christianity. In particular, Minh Mạng prosecuted [[Lê Văn Duyệt]], a former faithful general of Emperor [[Gia Long]], who had opposed his enthronement.Chapuis, p. 191 Since Lê Văn Duyệt had already died in July 1832, his tomb was profaned and inscribed with the words "This is the place where the infamous Lê Văn Duyệt was punished". ==Start of the revolt== [[File:Prince Canh MEP.jpg|thumb|The Lê Văn Khôi revolt sought the re-establishment of the line of [[Prince Cảnh]] (here during his 1787 visit in Paris).]] [[Lê Văn Khôi]], the adoptive son of general Lê Văn Duyệt, had also been imprisoned, but managed to escape on 10 May 1833. Soon, numerous people joined the revolt, in the desire to avenge Lê Văn Duyệt and challenge the legitimacy of the [[Nguyễn dynasty]]. ===Catholic support=== Lê Văn Khôi declared himself in favour of the restoration of the line of [[Prince Cảnh]], the original heir to [[Gia Long]] according to the rule of [[primogeniture]], in the person of his remaining son An-hoa. This choice was designed to obtain the support of Catholic missionaries and Vietnamese Catholics, who had supported the line of Prince Cảnh with Lê Văn Duyệt. Lê Văn Khôi further promised to protect Catholicism.McLeod, p. 30 On 18 May 1833, the rebels managed to take the [[Citadel of Saigon]] (''Thanh Phien-an''). Lê Văn Khôi was able to conquer six provinces of [[Gia Dinh]] in the span of one month.Chapuis, p. 192 The main actors of the revolt were Vietnamese Christians and Chinese settlers who had been suffering from the rule of Minh Mạng. ===Siamese support=== As Minh Mạng raised an army to quell the rebellion, Lê Văn Khôi fortified himself into the Saigon fortress and asked for the help of the [[Thai people|Siamese]]. [[Rama III]], king of Siam, accepted the offer and sent troops to attack the Vietnamese provinces of [[Ha-tien]] and [[An-giang]] and Vietnamese imperial forces in [[Laos]] and [[Cambodia]]. The Siamese troops were accompanied by 2,000 Vietnamese Catholic troops under the command of Father [[Nguyen Van Tam (catholic priest)|Nguyen Van Tam]]. These Siamese and Vietnamese forces were repelled in summer 1834 by General [[Truong Minh Giang]].McLeod, pp. 30–31 Lê Văn Khôi died in 1834, during the siege, and was succeeded by his 8-year-old son Le Van Cu. ==Defeat and repression== [[File:Martyrdom of Joseph Marchand.jpg|thumb|Torture and execution of Father [[Joseph Marchand]], on 5 November 1835]] [[File:Jean-Charles Cornay.jpg|thumb|Execution of [[Jean-Charles Cornay]], 20 September 1837]] It took three years for Minh Mạng to quell the rebellion and the Siamese offensive. When the fortress of Phien An was invaded in September 1835, 1,831 people were executed and buried in mass graves (now situated in [[3rd District]], Saigon). Only six survivors were temporarily spared, among whom were Le Van Cu, but also the French missionary Father [[Joseph Marchand]], of the [[Paris Foreign Missions Society]]. Marchand had apparently been supporting the cause of Lê Văn Khôi, and asked for the help of the Siamese army, through communications to his counterpart in Siam, [[Jean-Louis Taberd|Father Taberd]]. This revealed the strong Catholic involvement in the revolt. Father Marchand was tortured and executed on 5 November 1835, as was the child Le Van Cu. The failure of the revolt had a disastrous effect on the Christian communities of Vietnam.Wook, p. 95 New waves of persecutions against Christians followed, and demands were made to find and execute remaining missionaries. Anti-Catholic edicts to this effect were issued by Minh Mạng in 1836 and 1838. In 1836–1837 six missionaries were executed: Ignacio Delgado, Dominico Henares, [[Jean-Charles Cornay]], José Fernández, [[François Jaccard]], and Bishop [[Pierre Borie]].McLeod, p. 32[https://books.google.com/books?id=LvvzlLf9dFEC&pg=PA517&dq=Fran%C3%A7ois-Isidore+Gagelin&sig=ACfU3U2vAoHiwJK3OamylPqlNTLA2chwsA ''The Cambridge History of Christianity'', p. 517] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book| last=Chapuis |first=Oscar |title=A History of Vietnam: From Hong Bang to Tu Duc |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-313-29622-2}} * {{cite book |first=Mark W. |last=McLeod | title=The Vietnamese response to French intervention, 1862–1874 |publisher=Praeger | year=1991 |isbn=0-275-93562-0}} * {{cite book |first=Wook |last=Choi Byung | title=Southern Vietnam under the reign of Minh Mạng (1820–1841): central policies and local response |publisher=SEAP Publications | year=2004 |isbn=0-87727-138-0}} {{French Indochina}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Le Van Khoi Revolt}} [[Category:19th century in Vietnam]] [[Category:Nguyen dynasty]] [[Category:Military history of Vietnam]] [[Category:Rebellions in Vietnam]] [[Category:Rebellions in Asia]] [[Category:Rebellions against empires]] [[Category:Peasant revolts]] [[Category:1833 in Vietnam]] [[Category:1834 in Vietnam]] [[Category:1835 in Vietnam]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1833]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1834]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1835]] [[Category:19th-century rebellions]] [[Category:Wars involving Vietnam]] [[Category:Wars involving Thailand]] [[Category:19th century in Siam]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = National Organization of Sahrawi Women
الاتحاد الوطني للمرأة الصحراوية
''Unión Nacional de Mujeres Saharauis'' |image = Logo NOSW.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |formation = 1974 |type = Network for Sahrawi refugee women |headquarters = [[Sahrawi refugee camps]] |location = [[Tindouf province|Tindouf]], [[Algeria]] |language = [[Hassaniya]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] |leader_title = General Secretary |leader_name = Fatma Mehdi |website = [http://mujeressaharauisunms.blogspot.com.es/ mujeressaharauisunms.blogspot.com] }} {{Politics of Western Sahara}} The '''National Union of Sahrawi Women''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Unión Nacional de Mujeres Saharauis'', UNMS) is the [[women's wing]] of the '''[[Polisario Front]]'''. It was created in 1974, and claims to have 10,000 members, divided between the [[Refugee camps in Tindouf Province, Algeria|Sahrawi refugee camps]], the ''[[Free Zone (region)|Liberated territories]]'', the Moroccan-occupied part of [[Western Sahara]] and the ''Sahrawi diaspora'' (including for instance Spain, Mauritania or France). ==Organization== The organization is mostly active in the [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawi]] [[refugee camps]] in [[Tindouf]], [[Algeria]], where it is a powerful force within the POLISARIO and the [[Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic|Sahrawi republic]]. It is internationally active in organizing support for Sahrawi women and the Sahrawi cause, but also campaigns for women's rights within the exile community and in political decision-making. As a consequence of this, and of the special circumstances of the [[Western Sahara]] war years, the situation of Sahrawi women has improved noticeably. There are presently two women in the Sahrawi republic's government, the Minister of Culture '''Khadijah Hamdi''', and the Minister of Education '''Mariem Salek Hamada'''.[http://www.polisario.es/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2&Itemid=4 Datos Generales de la República Árabe Saharaui Democrática - Gobierno de la RASD tras el XII Congreso del Frente Polisario - Diciembre de 2007] {{es icon}} The UNMS is directed by a "National Committee" of 66 members, elected in the UNMS congress every 5 years. It is subdivided into several departments: * Department of External Relations and Cooperation * Department of Information and Culture * Department of Administration and Organization * Department of Occupied Towns and Emigration * Department of Social Affairs * Department of Health and Family Affairs * Department of Formation * Department of Education * Department of Production There are also departments for each [[Wilaya]]. The national committee is chaired by a Secretary General, elected also in the congresses, who is at the same time member of the Polisario Front national committee. '''Keltoum Khayati''', a former secretary general of the UNMS, fled to Morocco and is defending the Moroccan position in the conflict.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} '''Fatma Mehdi Hassan''' has been secretary general since 2002.[http://www.mujeresaharauis.es/index.php/mujeres-saharauis/biograficas/fatma-mehdi Fatma Mehdi] Mujeresaharauis.es The UNMS has been a member of the [[Women's International Democratic Federation]] (WIDF)[http://www.fdim-widf.com.br/indexingles/affiliateds/africa/repSaara.htm Union Nationale des Femmes Sahraouies] and the [[General Federation of Arab Women]] since 1977 and of the [[Pan-African Women's Organization]] (PAWO) since 1980.[http://www.arso.org/NUSW-1.htm National Union of Saharawi Women] ARSO.org ==Objectives== [[File:Saharako Emakumeen biltzarra - Congreso de la Union de Mujeres Saharauis - Saharauiak.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Sectorial workshop during the 5th Congress of the "National Union of Sahrawi Women", at the [[Sahrawi refugee camps]] (April 6, 2007).]] On the national level, the UNMS objectives are:[http://www.arso.org/NUSW-1.htm National Union of Saharawi Women][http://www.mujeresaharauis.es/index.php/UNMS/UNMS.html UNMS] {{es icon}} * Sensitize Saharawi women about their role in the struggle for the liberation and independence of the Western Sahara. * Orient women in the social and political fields to improve their level of education and training (literacy campaigns, scholastic and professional training, political seminars, etc.). * Aware women about their social and political rights, to guarantee an effective participation in the present and in the future. * Deepen in the role of the family, specially on educative level, guaranteeing an equal education between boys and girls, with the basis of respect and equality in society. * Concern women about the importance of the prevention on the health field. * Solidarity with our compatriots in the occupied zones, constantly facing the Moroccan aggression, being victims of discrimination and suffering. On the international level, the UNMS objectives are: * Implementation of decisions and strategies concerning women, particularly the "'''Strategy of Nairobi'''". * Establishment of security and peace in the world, equality between the sexes as the basis for all progress and development and the reinforcement of human rights and democracy. * Monitoring of the situation of the women worldwide, knowing that all work for the same objectives, despite the religious, political or social situation. * Enhance the relations with as many women's organizations worldwide, with the aim of: ** Broaden the base of coalition and solidarity with our people's struggle generally and our women particularly. ** Achieve material and financial support for the UNMS projects for woman's formation in the refugee camps. ** Denounce War and Racism, in which women and children used to be the first victims. ** Denounce the violation of women rights. [[File:UNMS V Congress.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Opening session of the 5th Congress of the "National Union of Sahrawi Women", at the Sahrawi refugee camps (April 5, 2007).]] ==Congresses== * 1st Congress: "Martyr Jueta Hadda Laulad" (March 23–25, 1985). * 2nd Congress: "Martyr Jnaza Ayad" (February 24–26, 1990). * 3rd Congress: "Martyr Batul Sidi Sidali" (February 24–26, 1996). * 4th Congress: "Martyr Fatimatu Ahmed-Salem Baad" (March 29–31, 2002) * 5th Congress: "Martyr Maimuna Abdallahi Mohamed Lamin" (April 5–7, 2007) * 6th Congress: "Sahrawi women perpetuating the Gdeim Izik spirit" (April 20–24, 2011) ==See also== *[[Sahrawi Youth Union]] *[[Sahrawi Trade Union]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.facebook.com/MujeresSaharauisUNMS Mujeres Saharauis-UNMS] UNMS Facebook page {{es icon}} *[http://www.arso.org/UNFS-Homepage.htm NUSW page] Association pour un Référendum libre et régulier au Sahara Occidental {{en icon}}{{es icon}}{{fr icon}} *[http://www.mujeresaharauis.es/index.php/UNMS/UNMS.html UNMS page] Asociación de Mujeres Saharauis en España {{es icon}} *[http://www.arso.org/UNFS2002.wsc.htm New generation of Saharawi woman ready to go] Appeal of the "Western Sahara Campaign UK" on the 4th Congress of the NUSW *[https://www.diagonalperiodico.net/libertades/la-planificacion-familiar-no-es-prioridad-intentan-aniquilarnos-como-pueblo.html “La planificación familiar no es una prioridad, intentan aniquilarnos como pueblo”] Interview at Spanish newspaper [[Diagonal (newspaper)|Diagonal]] with Fatma El-Mehdi, UNMS Secretary General {{es icon}} *[http://vimeo.com/38398770 Fatma El Mehdi at CUNY Center for '''Oslo Symposium''' is a biennial [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[Christian right|Christian conservative]] conference, first arranged in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Venstre inviteres til nytt Oslo Symposium |url=http://www.dagen.no/Kristenliv/Venstre_inviteres_til_nytt_Oslo_Symposium-55555|work=Dagen|date=14 August 2012|language=Norwegian}}</ref> The initiative to the conference was taken by the organisation [[Kristenfolket]] in cooperation with [[International Christian Embassy Jerusalem|ICEJ]] and [[Norge Idag]], and it has been broadcast live by [[Visjon Norge]].<ref name="Dagen180315"/> The conference includes speeches by leading Norwegian and international commentators and politicians, including party leaders and government ministers.<ref name="Dagen180315">{{Cite news|title=Oslo Symposium 2015 - se talene her|url=http://www.dagen.no/Inspirasjon/Oslo-Symposium-2015---se-talene-her-179674|work=Dagen|date=18 March 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Borten Moe til konferanse som vil kaste regjeringen|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/senterpartiet/borten-moe-til-konferanse-som-vil-kaste-regjeringen/a/10091103/|work=VG|date=20 March 2011|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
The third conference, in 2015 for the first time had to be arranged with "massive" police security, due to a general threat evaluation by the [[Norwegian Police Security Service]], pointing to the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks|Paris]] and [[2015 Copenhagen shootings|Copenhagen]] terrorist attacks the two preceding months.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Kristen Oslo-konferanse får væpnet politivakt|url=http://www.osloby.no/nyheter/Kristen-Oslo-konferanse-far-vapnet-politivakt-7936418.html|work=Osloby|date=17 March 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Massivt politivakthold rundt Oslo Symposium |url=http://www.dagen.no/Nyheter/sikkerhet/Massivt-politivakthold-rundt-Oslo-Symposium-180864|work=Dagen|date=19 March 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref>

'''Perpetual Peace''' or '''Eternal Peace''' may refer to: *[[Perpetual peace]], a concept in Kantian philosophy Specific treaties: *[[Egyptian–Hittite peace treaty]], instituting an "eternal peace" between the [[Hittites|Hittite]] and [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] empires. *[[Perpetual Peace (532)]] (ἀπέραντος εἰρήνη), signed between the Byzantine and the Sassanid empires. *[[Ewiger Landfriede]], a ''pax perpetua'' agreed at the [[Diet of Worms in 1495]], which banned the right of [[feud|vendetta]] in the Holy Roman Empire. *[[Treaty of Perpetual Peace]] between England and Scotland (1502). *[[Perpetual Peace (1516)]], signed between the Swiss Confederacy and Francis I of France. *[[Treaty of Perpetual Peace (1686)]], signed between Russia and Poland-Lithuania. *[[Entente Cordiale]] (1904), a frame agreement consisting of a number of treaties that were intended to create perpetual peace between [[United Kingdom]] and [[France]].

'''Pondage''' usually refers to the comparably small water storage behind the [[weir]] of a [[run-of-the-river hydroelectric]] power plant. Such a power plant has considerably less storage than the reservoirs of large dams and conventional hydroelectric stations which can store water for long periods such as a dry season or year. With pondage, water is usually stored during periods of low electricity demand and hours when the power plant is inactive, enabling its use as a [[peaking power plant]] in dry seasons and a [[base load power plant]] during wet seasons.<ref name="Dwivedi">{{cite book|last=Dwivedi|first=A.K. Raja, Amit Prakash Srivastava, Manish|title=Power Plant Engineering|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P-7kM_VZqxcC&pg=PA354&lpg=PA354 |year=2006|publisher=New Age International|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-224-1831-7|page=354}}</ref> Ample pondage allows a power plant meet hourly [[Load balancing (electrical power)|load fluctuations]] for a period of a week or more.<ref name="HH">{{cite book|last=Joel De Witt Justin|first=William Pitcher Creager|title=Hydroelectric handbook|year=1950|publisher=Wiley|pages=162|oclc=1609321|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3b6hfhe2okC&q=Hydroelectric+handbook&dq=Hydroelectric+handbook&hl=en&ei=c3BvTfeFDMjQceLf5fgC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Wadhwa|first=C.L.|title=Generation, distribution, and utilization of electrical energy|year=1993|publisher=New Age International (P) Ltd.|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-224-0073-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l1NQttrOQioC&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20 |edition=Rev. |page=20}}</ref>
As a daily hydropeaking cylcle of a hydro power plant with pondage results in fast rising river levels downstream, environmental regulations often restrict the full use of the dispatchability as a [[Peaking_power_plant|peaker]].
==Calculation== Because of the possibility of limited pondage, calculating its effect on power generation is important in determining how often the plant can be operated. The ''pondage factor'' is a rough index of the amount pondage needed when the stream flow is constant and the plant is operational during specific periods. It is calculated by the ratio of total inflow hours per week to the hours the power plant will be operated in that same period.<ref name=raghun>{{cite book|last=Raghunath|first=H.M.|title=Hydrology : principles, analysis, and design|year=2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-N1G5VSoRngC&pg=PA288&lpg=PA288 |publisher=New Age International|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-224-1825-2|edition=Rev. 2nd |page=288}}</ref> For example, if a river has an inflow for seven days a week and the plant operates for five of those days for eight hours: :<math>\frac{7 \times 24}{5 \times 8} = 4.2</math> 24-hour inflows and plant operation would have a pondage factor of one.
If power is used for twelve hours per day and during the inactive hours, relatively all inflows can be stored, then power can be doubled during active hours. In 12 hours there are 43,200 seconds and in {{Convert|1|acre.ft|m3|0|abbr=on}} there are {{Convert|43560|ft3|0|abbr=on}}. This gives an estimation and guide that for twelve hours of pondage, there must be as much storage available in the pond as cubic feet per section received.<ref name="HH"/>

{{Economics sidebar}} In [[developmental economics]], the '''Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle''' (also called the '''Growth-Inequality-Poverty Triangle''' or '''GIP Triangle''') refers to the idea that a country's change in poverty can be fully determined by its change in income growth and income inequality. According to the model, a development strategy must then also be based on income growth and income inequality.<ref name = "ReferenceF">{{cite web|last=Gelaw|first=Fekadu|title=The Relationship between Poverty, Inequality, and Growth in the Rural Ethiopia: Micro Evidence|date=August 2009|url=http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/51915/2/648,%20Fekadu%20G%20-%203.pdf|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|last=Bourguignon|first=François|title=The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTPGI/Resources/342674-1206111890151/15185_ICRIER_paper-final.pdf|date= February 2004|work=World Bank Website|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle model was created by [[François Bourguignon]], the former [[Chief Economist]] (2003-2007) of the [[World Bank]].
{{TOC limit|4}}
==Background==
The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle was originally introduced by Bourguignon in a paper presented at the Conference on Poverty, Inequality and Growth in Paris on November 13, 2003. A modified version of the paper was presented at the Indian Council for Research on International Economic Relations in New Delhi on February 4, 2004.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Economists working for international organizations like the World Bank use the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle to create poverty reduction strategies that include both steps to reduce inequality and stimulate growth. Economists have used the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle to study poverty in both [[developing countries]] and [[developed countries]], including China, Egypt, India, Mexico, and Nigeria.<ref name = "ReferenceD">{{cite web|title=The Growth-Inequality-Poverty Triangle Implication for the Development Strategy in Developing Countries|date=December 2004|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/DEC/Resources/84797-1104785060319/Cairo_ECES_1210final.pdf|work=Egyptian Center for Economic Studies|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> <ref name="ReferenceA"/> <ref name = "ReferenceJ">{{cite web|title=Growth, Inequality, and Poverty in Nigeria|last=Aigbokhan|first=Ben E.|date=February 2008|url=http://www.uneca.org/sites/default/files/publications/growthinequalitypoverty.pdf|accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref>
In 2013, a study of the 138 countries over the period 2005 to 2010 found that the basic ideas of Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle hold and that both growth and inequality impact absolute poverty as Bourguignon described.<ref name = "ReferenceI">{{cite journal|last1=Khan|first=Muhammad Azhar|last2=Khan|first2=Muhammad Zahir|last3=Zaman|first3=Khalid|last4=Hassan|first4=Umar|last5=Umar|first5=Sobia|title=Global estimates of growth–inequality–poverty (GIP) triangle: evidence from World Bank's classification countries|journal=Quality & Quantity|volume=48|issue=5|pages=2631–2646|date=July 2013|doi=10.1007/s11135-013-9912-7}}</ref>
==Model==
[[File:Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle.png|Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle|left|thumb|x150px|''The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle, by [[François Bourguignon]].'']]
The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle can be drawn as a triangle with arrows pointing out of each corner. At the top of the triangle is "absolute poverty." This refers to the percent of the population below the income [[poverty line]]. At the bottom left of the triangle is "inequality" or "distribution." This refers to differences in income across a population. At the bottom right of the triangle is "growth." This refers to the change in income for a population (for example, a change in [[GDP]]).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The arrows pointing out of "absolute poverty," "growth," and "inequality" in the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle represent cause and effect. In the model, inequality and growth affect each other and both of them affect absolute poverty.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Bourguignon defines the change in poverty as a function of growth, distribution, and changes in distribution: Δ poverty ≡ F(growth, distribution, Δ distribution). This equation assumes small changes in poverty.<ref name="ReferenceD"/> Bourguignon uses per capita income ([[GDP]] per capita) as the measure of growth and the [[Gini Index]] as the measure of inequality in his model.<ref name = "ReferenceH">{{cite web|last=Lopez|first=J. Humberto|title=Pro-poor growth: a review of what we know (and of what we don't)|date=September 2004|url=http://www.eldis.org/vfile/upload/1/document/0708/DOC17880.pdf|accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref>
==Significance==
The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle model differs from previous models of poverty in that it looks at the interactions between growth and inequality, rather than considering the two separately. On the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle, the bottom points of the triangle are boxed together under the heading of "development strategy," because Bourguignon believed the mix of policies to reduce poverty should depend on that relationship between growth and inequality.<ref name = "ReferenceA"/>
The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle model implies that reducing poverty requires a combination of country-wide policies focused on growth and country-wide policies focused on reducing inequality. Development strategies that focus on only one of these miss opportunities to reduce absolute poverty. The model describes that a change in inequality affects absolute poverty in two ways. First, a change in relative poverty affects absolute poverty by immediately changing the number of people below the poverty line. Second, a change in relative poverty changes the [[growth elasticity of poverty]]. A redistribution of income means more poverty reduction for a given amount of growth. The consequence of this is that policies that focus only on growth without considering distribution limit poverty reduction in two ways.<ref name = "ReferenceB">{{cite web|last=Grammy|first=Abbas|last2=Assane|first2=Djeto|title=The Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle Hypothesis: An Empirical Examination|date=November 2006|url=http://www.econmodels.com/upload7282/a77f04149bbad14085ce30ac170e7da0.pdf|work=Journal of Policy Model|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref><ref name = "ReferenceC">{{cite web|title=Inequality Matters|last=Kapoor|first=Radhicka|url=http://www.gdn.int/admin/uploads/editor/files/2013Conf_Papers/RadickaKapoor_ppt.pdf|work=ICRIER|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> Economists theorize that for this reason sub-Saharan Africa and other less developed countries will not be able to meet poverty goals like the [[Millennium Development Goals]] through growth alone.<ref name = "ReferenceK">{{cite web|last=Naschold|first=Felix|title=Inequality Briefing|url=http://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/3876.pdf|date=March 2002|work=Overseas Development Institute|accessdate=5 November 2014}}</ref>
==Controversy==
Critics argue that the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle looks at aggregate concepts in a way that ignores the processes behind those concepts. Critics say terms like "poverty," "inequality," and "growth" are too broad. Instead, critics suggest that poverty should be traced back to individual behavior.<ref name = "ReferenceG">{{cite book |last=Ferreira |first=Francisco H.G. |editor-last=Jefferson |editor-first=Philip N. |title=The Oxford Handbook of the Economics of Poverty|publisher=Oxford University Press |date=November 2012 |pages=427–462 |chapter=Distributions in Motion: Economic Growth, Inequality, and Poverty Dynamics}}</ref> Developmental economists [[Abhijit Banerjee]] and [[Esther Duflo]] argue that cross-country data cannot be used to give any meaningful insight on topics like poverty and inequality.<ref name = "ReferenceG"/>
Critics also argue that the simplified nature of the model means that it misses factors that affect absolute poverty. Poverty itself can be considered a barrier for economic growth, meaning that the Poverty-Growth-Inequality Triangle would need to consider the effect of poverty on growth.<ref name = "ReferenceI"/> Other economists argue that the triangle should include financial instability, crises, the business cycle, and their effects on poverty. Finally, many economists believe that there is a strong link between education, literacy rates, and poverty, and that the focus on decreasing poverty should lie in targeting these areas in addition to inequality and growth.<ref name = "ReferenceE">{{cite journal|last=Chemili|first=Leila|last2=Smida|first2=Mourir|title=Interaction between Poverty, Growth, and Inequality during the Crisis: A Panel Data Study|journal=International Journal of Economics and Finance|volume=5|issue=5|url=http://www.ccsenet.org/journal/index.php/ijef/article/view/26709/0|date=May 2013|accessdate=4 November 2014|doi=10.5539/ijef.v5n5p120}}</ref>
==See also== *[[François Bourguignon]] *[[Developmental economics]] *[[Poverty reduction]]

[[Manuel Rodríguez Orellana]] |foundation = 20 October 1946 |ideology = [[Independence movement in Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican Independence]][https://books.google.com/books?id=eelxKbo2UDUC&pg=PA21 ''National Performances: The Politics of Class, Race, and Space in Puerto Rican Chicago.''] Ana Y. Ramos-Zayas. University of Chicago Press. 2003. Pages 21-22. Retrieved 7 October 2013.
[[Social democracy]]
[[Left-wing populism]]
[[Left-wing nationalism]] |headquarters = [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] |international = [[Socialist International]] |website = [http://Independencia.net/ Independencia.net] |country = Puerto Rico |native_name = Partido Independentista Puertorriqueño |name = Puerto Rican Independence Party |logo = [[Image:PIP.logo.gif|PIP logo.|200px]] |leader1_title = Vice-president |leader1_name = [[María De Lourdes Santiago|María de Lourdes Santiago Negrón]] |leader2_title = Executive President |leader2_name = [[Fernando Martín García]] |leader3_title = Representative |leader3_name = Víctor García San Inocencio | youth_wing = Juventud PIP |position = [[Center-left]] |colors = [[Green]] & [[White]] |flag = [[Image:Flag of the Puerto Rican Independence Party.svg|150px]] |seats1_title = Seats in the [[Puerto Rico Senate|Senate]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|1|30|{{Independence Party (Puerto Rico)/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = Seats in the [[House of Representatives of Puerto Rico|House of Representatives]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|1|51|{{Independence Party (Puerto Rico)/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[Municipalities of Puerto Rico|Municipalities]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|78|{{Independence Party (Puerto Rico)/meta/color}}}} |}} The '''Puerto Rican Independence Party''' ({{lang-es|Partido Independentista Puertorriqueño}}, PIP) is a [[Social democracy|social-democratic]]{{cite book|author=Lester McGrath-Andino|chapter=Intifada: Church–State Conflict in Vieques, Puerto Rico|editor1=Gastón Espinosa|editor2=Virgilio P. Elizondo|editor3=Jesse Miranda|title=Latino Religions and Civic Activism in the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eRTGXR2UVzMC&pg=PA266|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-516228-8|page=266}}{{cite book|author=Alfredo Lopez|title=Dona Licha's Island: Modern Colonialism in Puerto Rico|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-la4qaF_8gIC&pg=PA127|year=1987|publisher=South End Press|isbn=978-0-89608-257-1|page=127}} [[List of political parties in Puerto Rico|political party in Puerto Rico]] that campaigns for the [[Independence movement in Puerto Rico|independence of Puerto Rico]] from [[United States]] [[suzerainty]].Berrios-Martinez, Ruben; "Puerto rico—Lithuania in Reverse?"; ''The Washington Post'', Pg. A23; 23 May 1990. Those who follow the PIP ideology are usually called ''independentistas'', ''pipiolos'', or sometimes just ''pro-independence activists''.Wallace, Carol J.; "Translating Laughter: Humor as a Special Challenge in Translating the Stories of [[Ana Lydia Vega]]"; The Journal of the Midwest [[Modern Language Association]] (MLA), Vol. 35, No. 2, Translating in and across Cultures (Autumn, 2002), pp. 75-87 == History == The party began as the electoral wing of the [[Puerto Rican independence movement]]. It is the largest of the independence parties, and the only one that is on the ballot during elections (other candidates must be added in by hand). In 1948, two years after being founded, the PIP gathered 10.2% of the votes in the island. In 1952, two years after an armed uprising of the [[Puerto Rican Nationalist Party]], it obtained 19% of the votes, its highest electoral support ever, which made it the second electoral party on the island for a moment. In 1956 it took 12.4% of the votes; in 1960 3.1%; in 1964, 4%; in 1968, 3.5; in 1972, 5.4; in 1976, 5.7; in 1980, 5.4; in 1984, 3.6, and in 1988, 5.5. In 2004 it obtained 2.7% of the votes, and in 2008 it took 2%.{{cite web|last=Comisión estatal de elecciones de Puerto Rico|title=web site|work=www.ceepur.org.}} === Foundation === The party was founded on October 20, 1946, by [[Gilberto Concepción de Gracia]] (1909–1968) and his colleague [[:es:Fernando Milán Suárez|Fernando Milán Suárez]]. They felt the independence movement had been "betrayed" by the [[Popular Democratic Party (Puerto Rico)|Popular Democratic Party]], whose ultimate goal had originally been independence. === FBI surveillance of the party === In 2003, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported the following about the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] publicly admitting it had directed "tremendously destructive" efforts against various organizations, including the Puerto Rican Independence Party: {{quote|They include a 1961 directive from Mr. Hoover to seek information on 12 independence movement leaders, six of them operating in New York, "concerning their weaknesses, morals, criminal records, spouses, children, family life, educational qualifications and personal activities other than independence activities." The instructions were given under the domestic surveillance program known as Cointelpro, which aimed at aggressively monitoring antiwar, leftist and other groups in the United States and disrupting them. In the case of Puerto Rican independence groups, [[J. Edgar Hoover]]'s 1961 memo refers to 'our efforts to disrupt their activities and compromise their effectiveness.{{cite book|last1=Fernandez|first1=Ronald|title=The Disenchanted Island: Puerto Rico and the United States in the Twentieth Century|date=1 Jan 1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group,|page=213|url=https://books.google.be/books?id=JfJYJ9u4JP4C&pg=PA213}} Scholars say the papers provide invaluable additions to the recorded history of Puerto Rico. "I expect that this will alter somewhat the analysis of why independence hasn't made it,' said [[Felix V. Matos Rodriguez|Félix V. Matos Rodríguez]], director of the center at Hunter{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. 'In the 1940s, independence was the second-largest political movement in the island, (after support for commonwealth status), and a real alternative. But it was criminalized.' The existence of the FBI papers came to light during a [[US House of Representatives]] Appropriations Subcommittee hearing in 2000, when Representative [[Jose E. Serrano|José E. Serrano]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] questioned [[Louis J. Freeh]], then FBI director, on the issue. Freeh gave the first public acknowledgment of the federal government's Puerto Rican surveillance and offered a mea culpa. 'Your question goes back to a period, particularly in the 1960s, when the F.B.I. did operate a program that did tremendous destruction to many people, to the country and certainly to the F.B.I.,' Freeh said, according to transcripts of the hearing. Freeh said that he would make the files available 'and see if we can redress some of the egregious illegal action, maybe criminal action, that occurred in the past'.".{{cite web|url=http://www.thirdworldtraveler.com/Caribbean/FBI_PuertoRicanGroups.html|title=Decades of FBI Surveillance of Puerto Rican Groups by Mireya Navarro|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}}}} The FBI's surveillance of any person or organization advocating Puerto Rico's independence has been recognized by the FBI's top leadership.{{cite web|url=http://www.eldiariony.com/noticias/detail.aspx?section=25&desc=Editorial&id=1794932|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223002159/http://www.eldiariony.com/noticias/detail.aspx?section=25&desc=Editorial&id=1794932|title=El Diario/LA PRENSA OnLine |archivedate=23 February 2008|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}} The FBI's past surveillance of the pro-independence movement is detailed in 1.8 million documents, a fraction of which were released in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.pr-secretfiles.net/organizations_info.html?detail=8|title=pr-secretfiles.net|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pr-secretfiles.net/index.html|title=pr-secretfiles.net|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}} Then FBI Director [[Louis Freeh]] made an unprecedented admission to the effects that the FBI had engaged in egregious and illegal action from the 1930s to the 1990s, quite possibly involving the FBI in widespread crimes and violation of Constitutional rights against Puerto Ricans. He stunned a congressional budget hearing by conceding that his agency had violated the civil rights of many Puerto Ricans over the years and had engaged in "egregious illegal action, maybe criminal action."[https://books.google.com/books?id=pKqVpqGVsJYC&pg=PA94&lpg=PA94 America's Colony By Pedro A. Malavet, page 95] Accessed 14 July 2009. === 1970s === In 1971, the PIP gubernatorial candidate, [[Rubén Berríos]] led a protest against the [[US Navy]] in [[Culebra, Puerto Rico|Culebra]].The New York Times, "Protesters on Culebra Scuffle With Marines"; pg. 13, January 19, 1971. At that time, he was found guilty of trespassing federal lands and incarcerated for three months at Fox River State Penitentiary (''see also:'' [[Navy-Culebra protests]]).Berrios Martinez, Ruben; "From a Puerto Rican Prison"; The New York Times, pg. 47, 28 April 1971. During the 1972 elections, the PIP showed the largest growth in its history while running a [[democratic socialism|democratic socialist]], pro-worker, pro-poor campaign. One year later during a delegate assembly Rubén Berríos declared that the party was not presenting a [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] platform and took the matter to the PIP's assembly which voted in favor of the party's current stance in favor of [[social democracy]].{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} The Marxist–Leninist faction, called the "terceristas", split into several groups. The biggest of them went into the [[Popular Socialist Movement]], while the rest went into the [[Puerto Rican Socialist Party]]. === 1990s === {{Social democracy sidebar}} In 1999, PIP leaders, especially [[Rubén Berríos]], became involved in the [[Navy-Vieques protests]] started by many citizens of [[Vieques, Puerto Rico|Vieques]] against the presence of the [[US military]] in the island-[[Municipalities of Puerto Rico|municipality]] (''see also:'' [[Cause of Vieques]]).[http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=83278&page=1 ABC News: ''Dozens of Puerto Rican Protesters Arrested - Marshals Raid Activists' Homes''; by Vilma Perez, 3 July 2000.] ===2008 election=== During the 2008 elections, the PIP lost official recognition for the second time, obtaining 2.04% of the gubernatorial vote. Loss of recognition was official on January 2, 2009. The minimum vote percentage to keep official recognition is 3.0% as per the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico law. The party also lost both of its seats in the [[Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico|legislature]], where they had had one seat in each house. In May 2009, the party submitted more than 100,000 signed petitions to the Puerto Rico's elections commission and regained legal status.{{cite news|url=http://www.laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=334663&CategoryId=14092|title=Puerto Rican Independence Party Regains Legal Status|date=2009-15-2009|publisher=Latin American Herald Tribune|accessdate=2009-05-16}} ===2012 election=== During the 2012 elections, the PIP lost official recognition for the third time, obtaining 2.5% of the gubernatorial vote. Loss of recognition will be official on January 2, 2013. The minimum vote percentage to keep official recognition is 3.0% as per the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico law.{{cite web|url=http://www.vocero.com/pierde-su-franquicia-el-pip/|title=El Vocero de Puerto Rico|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130205200620/http://www.vocero.com/pierde-su-franquicia-el-pip/|archivedate=5 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===2016 election=== For the 2016 election, [[María de Lourdes Santiago|Senator María de Lourdes Santiago]] was the party's nominee. She obtained 33,452 votes and came in fifth place, with 2.1% of the vote. Some of the senator's main policies for the election are outlined below[http://www.univision.com/puerto-rico/wlii/noticias/politica-de-educacion/maria-de-lourdes-santiago-presenta-su-propuesta-educativa ''Politica de Educacion: María de Lourdes Santiago presenta su propuesta educativa.''] Inter News Services. Univision de Puerto Rico. 27 July 2016. Accesses 28 March 2018. * Increase the basic teacher's salary to $3,000 per month.http://www.univision.com/puerto-rico/wlii/noticias/politica-de-educacion/maria-de-lourdes-santiago-presenta-su-propuesta-educativa * Universal healthcare through the National Health Plan.http://www.independencia.net/2015-11-30-02-48-56/comunicados/1863-maria-de-lourdes-santiago-presenta-su-propuesta-ambiental * Merge the [[House of Representatives of Puerto Rico|House of Representatives]] and the [[Senate of Puerto Rico|Senate]] into one [[unicameral]] chamber, whereby the members are elected by [[proportional representation]].http://www.independencia.net/2015-11-30-02-48-23/reforma-gubernamental * Change the status of [[Puerto Rico]] to that of a [[Associated State|Freely Associated State]].http://endata.prdecide.elnuevodia.com/legislativo/100 == International support == {{ external media | align = center | audio1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fMxMbrc9A2I You may watch and listen to a Puerto Rican Independence Party political campaign ad featuring Ruben Berrios and the voice of José Feliciano in an interpretation of Antonio Caban Vales' "''Verde Luz'''" here.] }} The PIP cause receives moral support by international organizations. Examples of these are the [[Socialist International]] (the largest organization of political parties in the world), including fifteen political parties which are in power in Latin America. The [[government of Cuba]] also supports it, as well as the ex-president of [[Panama]], [[Martín Torrijos]], and a wide group of world-recognized writers and artists."Panama requests Latin America to support Puerto Rican independence"; ''Dominican Today;'' 19 November 2006"Prominentes figuras de América Latina apoyan la independencia de Puerto Rico - Escritores y artistas declaran su adhesión a la Proclama de Panamá" www.independencia.net/topicos/panama/cpi_panama_nov06.html On January 26, 2007, the [[Nobel Prize]] laureate [[Gabriel García Márquez]] joined other figures such as [[Mario Benedetti]], [[Ernesto Sábato]], [[Thiago de Mello]], [[Eduardo Galeano]], [[Carlos Monsiváis]], [[Pablo Armando Fernández]], [[Jorge Enrique Adoum]], [[Pablo Milanés]], [[Luis Rafael Sánchez]], [[Mayra Montero]] and [[Ana Lydia Vega]], in supporting independence for Puerto Rico and joining the [[Latin American and Caribbean Congress in Solidarity with Puerto Rico's Independence]], which approved a resolution favoring the island's right to assert its independence, as ratified unanimously by political parties hailing from 22 countries in November 2006. García Márquez's push for the recognition of Puerto Rico's independence was obtained at the behest of the Puerto Rican Independence Party. His pledge for support to the [[Puerto Rican Independence Movement]] was part of a wider effort that emerged from the Latin American and Caribbean Congress in Solidarity with Puerto Rico's Independence. ==PIP anti-war mobilization and protests== As reported in numerous media, the PIP's leadership and active members participated in [[anti-war]] protests and mobilization to resist the [[Iraq War]] and oppose the U.S. government's efforts to encourage Puerto Ricans to enlist in the [[U.S. Armed Forces]]. The ''[[Washington Post]]'' wrote in August 2007 that "on this island with a long tradition of military service, pro-independence advocates are tapping the territory's growing anti-Iraq war sentiment to revitalize their cause. As a result, 57 percent of Puerto Rico's 10th-, 11th- and 12th-graders, or their parents, have signed forms over the past year withholding contact information from the Pentagon. ... For five years, PIP has issued opt-out forms to about 120,000 students in Puerto Rico and encouraged them to sign—and independista activists expect this year to mark their most successful effort yet."{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/17/AR2007081702175_pf.html|title=Recruiting For Iraq War Undercut in Puerto Rico|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=25 April 2016}} The article also quoted [[Juan Dalmau]], then-secretary general of the Puerto Rican Independence Party as saying: if the death of a Puerto Rican soldier is tragic, it's more tragic if that soldier has no say in that war [with Iraq]" and that he did not want the children of [[Puerto Rico]] to become "colonial cannon meat." Another article in ''[[The Progressive]]'' also reported on PIP's anti-war activity. It was written three years earlier, in 2004, but it still noted that "some groups like the Puerto Rico Bar Association and the Independence Party have registered strong protests against the deployments. In an attempt to draw attention to Puerto Ricans' lack of elected representatives, even the usually pro-U.S. statehood party has raised concerns about the disproportionate body count suffered by islanders."{{cite web|url=http://progressive.org/media_898|title=Puerto Rican involvement in Iraq comes with no representation |work=The Progressive|accessdate=25 April 2016}} Two years later, it was reported that PIP, along with hundreds of other supporters of Puerto Rican independence "blocked the entrance to the U.S. Federal Courthouse here on Feb. 20 to denounce recent FBI raids against the homes and workplaces of ... supporters of Puerto Rican independence...and the growing repression by the FBI against the independence movement in general." This demonstration reportedly marked the beginning of PIP "campaign to get the FBI out of Puerto Rico."{{cite web|url=http://www.workers.org/2006/world/puerto-rico-0302/|title=Puerto Rican Independence Party protests FBI attacks on activists and the|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}} ==PIP stance on Puerto Rico's economic crisis and taxation system== During the 2005–2007 Puerto Rico economic crisis, the Puerto Rican Independence Party submitted various bills that would have taxed corporations making $1 million or more in annual net profits an extra ten percent above the average tax rate these corporations pay, which hovers around 5%.Cruz, José A.; "Puerto Rico's crisis highlights its colonial status"; ''People's Weekly World''. (National Edition). New York: Jun 17-Jun 23, 2006. Vol. 21, Iss. 3; pg. 7. The PNP and the PPD parties amended the bill, taxing the corporations the traditional lower rate. Despite objections presented by the PIP, the PNP and PPD also allowed the companies to claim the additional tax as a credit on next year's bill, making the "tax", in effect, a one-year loan. Puerto Rico has been said "There is no place in the territorial limits of the United States that provides such an advantageous base for exporters. " Because of this, many US companies moved their headquarters and manufacturing facilities there. This is why the PNP and PPD believed the tax increase would exacerbate the problems{{cite web|url=http://www.offshore-manual.com/taxhavens/PuertoRico.html|title= — Offshore Manual - We walk the walk, and talk the talk! --|publisher=|accessdate=25 April 2016}} == Party symbol == [[Image:Flag of the Puerto Rican Independence Party.svg|thumb|250px|The PIP's symbol is a [[Scandinavia]]n white [[cross]] on a green [[flag]]; because of this and its commitment to protecting the environment and promoting [[sustainable development]], it is identified as the ''green'' party by both the voting public and ballots{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}.]] The flag's green color stands for the hope of becoming free, and the white cross stands for the sacrifice and commitment of the party with democracy.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} The flag's design is based on the first [[Nationalism|national]] flag ever flown by Puerto Ricans, which is also the current flag of the municipality of [[Lares, Puerto Rico|Lares]], location where the first relatively successful attempt of revolutionary insurgency in Puerto Rico, called [[Grito de Lares]], took place on September 23, 1868. The [[Lares, Puerto Rico|Lares]] flag is, on the other hand, similar to that of the [[Dominican Republic]], since the Grito's mastermind, [[Ramón Emeterio Betances]], not only admired the Dominican pro-independence struggle, but was also half-Dominican himself. The party's flag is based on the [[Nordic Cross]] flag design. Nordic Cross flags, or [[Latin cross]] flags, are a common design in [[Scandinavia]] and other parts of the world, and in theory, the PIP's emblem belongs to this family of flags. ==Disfranchisement due to residence in Puerto Rico== United States citizens residing in the [[Commonwealth (United States insular area)|U.S. commonwealth]] of Puerto Rico do not hold the right to vote in U.S. presidential elections. Although Puerto Rican residents elect a [[Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico|Resident Commissioner]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]], that official may not participate in votes determining the final passage of legislation. Furthermore, Puerto Rico holds no representation of any kind in the [[United States Senate]]. Both the Puerto Rican Independence Party and the [[New Progressive Party of Puerto Rico]] officially oppose the island's political status quo and consider Puerto Rico's lack of federal representation to be disfranchisement. The remaining political organization, the [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]], is less active in its opposition of this case of disfranchisement but has officially stated that it favors fixing the remaining "deficits of democracy" that the [[Clinton administration|Clinton]] and [[George W. Bush administration]]s have publicly recognized in writing through Presidential Task Force Reports. == Electoral performance == This chart shows the electoral performance of the Puerto Rican Independence Party in all senatorial elections since 2000.electionspuertorico.org {| class="sortable wikitable" |- !
